choices.text: The "v" wave corresponds to atrial contraction.
The "x" descent is caused by atrial contraction.
The "y" descent occurs during ventricular systole.

questions.text: The image shows a normal jugular venous pulse (JVP) waveform with labeled components. Which of the following statements about the JVP waveform is correct?
questions.solution:
1. The "a" wave represents atrial systole:
    • Mnemonic: "A for Atrial contraction."
    • The "a" wave is the first upward deflection in the JVP waveform and is caused by atrial contraction pushing blood into the right ventricle.
    • It occurs just before the first heart sound (S1).
  2. The "v" wave corresponds to atrial contraction:
    • Mnemonic: "V for Venous filling".
    • The "v" wave represents venous filling of the right atrium when the tricuspid valve is closed during late ventricular systole.
    • It does not occur due to atrial contraction.
  3. The "x" descent is caused by atrial contraction:
    • Mnemonic: "X for relaXation".
    • The "x" descent occurs due to atrial relaxation and the downward pull of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole.
    • Atrial contraction causes the "a" wave, not the "x" descent.
  4. The "y" descent occurs during ventricular systole:
    • Mnemonic: "Y for emptYing".
    • The "y" descent represents rapid emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole.
    • It occurs during ventricular diastole, not systole.

Easy Way to Remember:

"ABCDE of JVP Waves"

  • A: Atrial contraction (a wave).
  • C: Closure of the tricuspid valve causes a bulge into the atrium (c wave).
  • X: RelaXation of the atrium (x descent).
  • V: Venous filling (v wave).
  • Y: EmptYing of the atrium into the ventricle (y descent).

Key to Remember: "Atrial contraction = a wave, RelaXation = X descent, Venous filling = v wave, EmptYing = y descent".

Tags:

Topic Name: Jugular venous pulse

Difficulty level: Must know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st principles of internal medicine, page number 1817

questions.text: A 35 yr old young male after sustaining head trauma is admitted in emergency department. He is stuporous. NCCT Brain shows extradural haemorrhage. Which of the following signs is seen earliest when any patient of extradural haemorrhage presents with the type of herniation shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
A-Uncal herniation, B-Central herniation, C-Transfalcine herniation, D-Foraminal herniation

Uncal transtentorial herniation refers to impaction of the anterior medial temporal gyrus (the uncus) into the tentorial opening just anterior to and adjacent to the midbrain .The uncus can compress the third nerve as the nerve traverses the subarachnoid space, causing enlargement of the ipsilateral pupil as the first sign (the fibers subserving parasympathetic pupillary function are located peripherally in the nerve). The coma that typically follows is due to lateral displacement of the midbrain (and therefore the RAS) against the opposite tentorial edge by the displaced parahippocampal gyrus compressing the opposite cerebral peduncle and producing a Babinski sign and ipsilateral hemiparesis (the Kernohan-Woltman sign).

  1. Central transtentorial herniation denotes a symmetric downward movement of the thalamic structures through the tentorial opening with compression of the upper midbrain. Miotic pupils and drowsiness are the heralding signs, in contrast to a unilaterally enlarged pupil of the uncal syndrome. Both uncal and central transtentorial herniations cause progressive compression of the brainstem and RAS, with initial damage to the midbrain, then the pons, and finally the medulla.
  2. Transfalcial herniation (displacement of the cingulate gyrus under the falx and across the midline) and foraminal herniation (downward forcing of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum) which causes early compression of the medulla, respiratory arrest, and death.

Key to remember:

Tags:

Topic Name: Head trauma

Difficulty level: Good to know

Reference: Harrison's principle of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, page number:184

choices.text: Oral anticoagulation with a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC)
Rate control with a beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has no symptoms of heart failure, and his heart rate is 110 bpm and 112/74 mmHg. ECG shown as below. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Electrocardiogram of an irregularly irregular heart rhythm without discernable P waves. The disorganized atrial activation is best appreciated in lead V1 for this patient.

C) Rate control with a beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker:

  • For patients with stable AF and a heart rate >100 bpm, rate control is the first-line treatment.
  • Medications such as beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol) or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem, verapamil) are commonly used.
  • The goal is to reduce the ventricular rate and improve symptoms.

A) Immediate DC cardioversion:

  • Indicated in patients with hemodynamic instability (e.g., hypotension, syncope, angina, or severe heart failure) due to atrial fibrillation.
  • This patient is stable with no signs of instability, so immediate cardioversion is not required.

B) Oral anticoagulation with a DOAC:

  • Anticoagulation is indicated in patients with AF and CHA2DS2-VASc scores ≥2 in men or ≥3 in women.
  • Although necessary to reduce the risk of thromboembolism, anticoagulation is not the initial treatment priority.
  • It would be initiated along side rate or rhythm control.

D) Rhythm control with amiodarone:

  • Rhythm control is not the first-line strategy in most stable AF patients unless rate control fails or if there is a compelling reason to restore sinus rhythm (e.g., young age, severe symptoms).
  • Additionally, rhythm control drugs like amiodarone are used cautiously due to potential side effects.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Stable AF: Initial focus is on rate control (beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker).
  2. Anticoagulation: Evaluate thromboembolic risk using the CHA2DS2-VASc score to determine the need for anticoagulation.
  3. Rhythm Control or Cardioversion: Considered in symptomatic or refractory cases after initial rate control.

Mnemonic for AF Management in Stable Patients: "RAT"

  • R: Rate control first.
  • A: Anticoagulation to prevent stroke.
  • T: Timing for rhythm control if rate control fails or in specific cases.

Tags:

Topic Name: Atrial fibrillation

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's principle of internal Medicine, 21st edition, page number 1903

questions.text: A 32 year old female patient newly diagnosed as Dermatomyositis develops a periorbital violaceous erythema shown in below image. What is it called?
questions.solution:
Option D: The cutaneous signs of dermatomyositis may precede or follow the development of myositis by weeks to years. Cases lacking muscle involvement (i.e., dermatomyositis sine myositis or amyopathic dermatomyositis) have also been reported.

The most common manifestation is a purple-red discoloration of the upper eyelids, sometimes associated with scaling ("heliotrope" erythema;) and periorbital edema. Erythema on the cheeks and nose in a "butterfly" distribution may resemble the malar eruption of SLE.

Option B and D. Erythematous or violaceous thin, scaly plaques are common on the upper trunk and neck (shawl sign), the scalp, lateral aspects of the thighs (holster sign), and the extensor surfaces of the forearms and hands (tendon streaking).

Option C. Approximately one-third of patients have violaceous, flat-topped papules over the dorsal interphalangeal joints that are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis (Gottron's papules).

Thin violaceous papules and plaques on the elbows and knees of patients with dermatomyositis are referred to as Gottron's sign.

These lesions can be contrasted with the erythema and scaling on the dorsum of the fingers that spares the skin over the interphalangeal joints of some SLE patients.

Periungual telangiectasias and edema may be prominent in patients with dermatomyositis.

Key to remember:

  • Heliotrope erythema = "Purple eyelids" (think of heliotropes turning toward the light, much like the purple hue of the upper eyelids).
  • Other dermatomyositis signs include:
    • Shawl sign = Trunk/neck plaques.
    • Gottron's papules = Joints.
    • Holster sign = Lateral thighs.

Tags:

Topic Name: Dermatomyositis

Difficulty level: Must know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 405

questions.text: The karyotype shown in the image depicts a chromosomal abnormality. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The karyotype shows that 47 XXY chromosome.

One X chromosome is extra.

So, It is 47XXY

SO the diagnosis is Klinefelter syndrome

Option A.

The karyotype shows 47 chromosomes, with an additional X chromosome resulting in XXY.This is diagnostic of Klinefelter syndrome, a condition in males caused by the presence of one or more extra X chromosomes.

Clinical features include:

  • Tall stature with long limbs.
  • Hypogonadism with small testes.
  • Gynecomastia (breast development).
  • Often presents with infertility and reduced testosterone levels.

Option B.

Turner syndrome is associated with a 45,X karyotype, reflecting the absence of one X chromosome. The karyotype in the image does not show monosomy but rather an extra X chromosome, ruling out Turner syndrome.

Option C.

Down syndrome is characterized by trisomy 21, with three copies of chromosome 21 visible in the karyotype. The image depicts an extra X chromosome (XXY) rather than trisomy 21.

Option D.

A normal male karyotype is 46,XY, while the image shows 47 chromosomes, ruling out a normal karyotype.

Key to remember:

  • Klinefelter syndrome: 47,XXY (extra X chromosome).
  • Turner syndrome: 45,X (monosomy X).
  • Down syndrome: Trisomy 21 (three chromosome 21s).

Tags:

Topic Name: Genetic syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 3000

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiency can leads to the presentation shown in below image?
questions.solution:
Option C. The image shows "Casal's necklace", a hyperpigmented, scaly rash around the neck, pathognomonic of pellagra due to niacin deficiency.

Pellagra is characterized by the 3 D's:

  • Dermatitis (photosensitive, hyperpigmented skin).
  • Diarrhea.
  • Dementia.

Treatment of pellagra consists of oral supplementation with 100-200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days. High doses of nicotinic acid (2 g/d in a time-release form) are used for the treatment of elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels and/or low high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels, but without proven evidence to prevent cardiovascular disease. Severe cases can lead to death if untreated.

Nevertheless, nicotinic acid may be useful in patients with statin intolerance or severe hypertriglyceridemia.

Option A. Thiamine deficiency causes beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, not hyperpigmented dermatitis. Symptoms include neuropathy, cardiac failure, and encephalopathy.

Option B. Riboflavin deficiency causes ariboflavinosis, presenting with symptoms like cheilitis, glossitis, and angular stomatitis, not hyperpigmented skin lesions.

Option D. Pyridoxine deficiency causes irritability, depression, and microcytic anemia but not dermatitis like pellagra.

Key to Remember:

  • Niacin Deficiency = Pellagra:
    • "3 D's of Pellagra": Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia.

Tags:

Topic Name: Nutrition: Vitamin deficiency

Difficulty level: Must know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 2524

questions.text: A 34 year old female patient had dizziness and palpitations. On admission BP was 80/44 mmHg. Her ECG shown below. Which of the following is the correct intervention?
questions.solution:
ECG in lead II shows heart rate of >200 bpm and narrow QRS complex is present. Global ST depression is present in all leads and P wave is hidden in QRS complexes.

Option A. The interpretation is PSVT and since patient is hemodynamically unstable Cardioversion is the treatment of choice. Synchronized cardioversion is indicated in unstable PSVT. It delivers a timed shock synchronized to the QRS complex, restoring sinus rhythm.

Option B. Adenosine is the drug of choice for stable PSVT but is not recommended in unstable cases.

Option C. PCI is used for revascularization in acute coronary syndromes (e.g., STEMI). This patient has no evidence of coronary artery disease.

Option D. Amiodarone is used for ventricular arrhythmias or atrial fibrillation with pre-excitation syndromes. It is not the first-line treatment for PSVT.

Key to remember:

  • Stable PSVT: Start with vagal maneuvers → adenosine.
  • Unstable PSVT: Immediate synchronized cardioversion.

Mnemonic:

  • "Stable = Slow it, Unstable = Shock it":
    • Stable arrhythmias → pharmacological intervention.
    • Unstable arrhythmias → electrical cardioversion.

Tags:

Topic Name: Supraventricular arrythmias

Difficulty level: Must know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 1895

choices.text: Miliary TB is due to hematogenous spread of tubercle bacilli.
Sputum-smear microscopy is positive in most cases.
Eye examination may reveal choroidal tubercles, which are pathognomonic of miliary TB
It can be associated with Pancytopenia

questions.text: A 38 year old chronic alcoholic and I.V drug user had diagnosed HIV 3 months ago. At present patient had complaints of fever, cough, weight loss, anorexia since 1 month. His HRCT shows below. What is false statement regarding this image?
questions.solution:
Option A. Miliary TB is due to hematogenous spread of tubercle bacilli. Although in children it is often the consequence of primary infection, in adults it may be due to either recent infection or reactivation of old disseminated foci.

The lesions are usually yellowish granulomas 1-2 mm in diameter that resemble millet seeds (thus the term miliary, coined by nineteenth-century pathologists).

Clinical manifestations are nonspecific, depending on the predominant site of involvement. Fever, night sweats, anorexia, weakness, and weight loss are presenting symptoms in the majority of cases. At times, patients have a cough and other respiratory symptoms due to pulmonary involvement as well as abdominal symptoms.

Option C. Physical findings include hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Eye examination may reveal choroidal tubercles, which are pathognomonic of miliary TB, in up to 30% of cases. Meningismus occurs in fewer than 10% of cases. Pancytopenia is a common finding in miliary TB due to bone marrow involvement or hypersplenism.

A high index of suspicion is required for the diagnosis of miliary TB.

Frequently, CXR reveals a miliary reticulonodular pattern (more easily seen on underpenetrated film), although no radiographic abnormality may be evident early in the course and among HIV infected patients.

Other radiologic findings include large infiltrates, interstitial infiltrates (especially in HIV-infected patients), and pleural effusion.

Option B and D: Sputum-smear microscopy is negative in most cases. Various hematologic abnormalities may be seen, including anemia with leukopenia, lymphopenia, neutrophilic leukocytosis and leukemoid reactions, and polycythemia. Disseminated intravascular coagulation has been reported.

Elevation of alkaline phosphatase levels and other abnormal values in liver function tests are detected in patients with severe hepatic involvement. TST results may be negative in up to half of cases, but reactivity may be restored during chemotherapy.

Key to Remember:

  • Sputum microscopy is often negative in miliary TB, requiring alternate methods like cultures, nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), or biopsy for diagnosis.
  • Miliary TB is a systemic form of tuberculosis often seen in immunocompromised patients, requiring a high index of suspicion for diagnosis.

Mnemonic for Miliary TB Key Features:

  • "MILIARY":
    • M: Millet seed appearance on imaging.
    • I: Immunocompromised (HIV, malnourished).
    • L: Liver involvement (elevated alkaline phosphatase).
    • I: Infiltrates (reticulonodular on imaging).
    • A: Anemia and pancytopenia.
    • R: Retinal tubercles (choroidal tubercles).
    • Y: Years of reactivation from latent foci.

Tags:

Topic Name: Tuberculosis: Miliary TB

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 1367

choices.text: Severe ARDS is defined as PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 100 mmHg
Treat patient with low tidal volume

questions.text: A 48 year old male patient had complaint of the breathlessness on exertion and high grade fever and dry cough since 2 days. She is COVID 19 positive. The condition worsened and required ventilatory support within 1 day. The chest Xray taken and shown below. What is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Xray shows: A representative anteroposterior chest x-ray in the exudative phase of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) shows bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema that can be difficult to distinguish from left ventricular failure.

Option B.

  • ARDS is non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, caused by increased capillary permeability due to inflammation and alveolar damage, not by left ventricular failure.
  • The presence of diffuse infiltrates and acute onset respiratory failure are consistent with ARDS, not cardiogenic causes.
  • Cardiogenic pulmonary edema would present with elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) > 18 mmHg, which is not seen in ARDS.

Option A.

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is defined by the Berlin criteria:

  • Mild ARDS: PaO2/FiO2 between 200-300 mmHg.
  • Moderate ARDS: PaO2/FiO2 between 100-200 mmHg.
  • Severe ARDS: PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 100 mmHg, as seen in this critically ill COVID-19 patient.

Option C.

  • ARDS typically develops within 7 days of a precipitating event, such as pneumonia, sepsis, or trauma.
  • In this case, the rapid worsening of symptoms aligns with the diagnostic timeline for ARDS.

Option D.

The cornerstone of ARDS management includes lung-protective ventilation:

  • Use low tidal volume ventilation (4-8 mL/kg of ideal body weight) to prevent ventilator-induced lung injury.
  • Avoid high tidal volumes that can lead to overdistension and worsen barotrauma.

Key to remember

Mnemonic for ARDS (Berlin Criteria):

  • A-C-O-R-D:
    • A: Acute onset (≤ 7 days).
    • C: Chest X-ray (bilateral infiltrates).
    • O: Oxygenation (PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 mmHg).
    • R: Rule out cardiac causes.
    • D: Diffuse alveolar damage.

Tags:

Topic Name: Respiratory critical care:ARDS

Difficulty level: Must know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 2228

questions.text: The following image shows the coagulation cascade. Identify the drug acting on factor Thrombin(IIa)?
questions.solution:
Direct Oral Anticoagulants

Option C. The direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) include dabigatran, which inhibits thrombin, and

Option Aand B. Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, and Edoxaban, which inhibit factor Xa.

These drugs have a rapid onset and offset of action and have half-lives that permit once- or twice-daily administration.

Designed to produce a predictable level of anticoagulation, the DOACs are more convenient to administer than warfarin because they are given in fixed doses without routine coagulation monitoring.

Key to remember:

  • Factor Xa inhibitors: Apixaban, Edoxaban, Rivaroxaban.
  • Thrombin (Factor IIa) inhibitors: Dabigatran, Argatroban, Bivalirudin.

Clinical Uses:

  • Warfarin: Long-term anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation, DVT/PE.
  • Heparin: Acute anticoagulation in hospitalized patients.
  • DOACs: Stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, DVT/PE.
  • Thrombolytics: Acute MI, ischemic stroke, massive PE.

Tags:

Topic Name: Anticoagulant drugs

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 451

questions.text: A 58 year old male patient, a chronic beedi smoker and a known case of the HTN on 3 medications. Patient forgets to take medication for 3 days. Patient suddenly became unconscious and fell down. Patient was immediately taken to emergency department. NCCT brain showed hemorrhagic stroke. Which of the following statement is false regarding management of raised ICP in this patient?
questions.solution:
The NCCT brain shows Hemorrhage at Right gangliocapsular region with midline shift.

Option C. Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used to reduce edema caused by vasogenic edema, such as in brain tumors or abscesses. However, dexamethasone is not effective in reducing ICP in hemorrhagic or ischemic stroke and is not recommended for managing raised ICP in these settings.

Option A. Mannitol, an osmotic diuretic, is commonly used to reduce raised ICP by creating an osmotic gradient that draws fluid out of the brain tissue into the vasculature, reducing cerebral edema. It is indicated in the acute management of raised ICP in hemorrhagic stroke. However, its use must be carefully monitored in patients with renal dysfunction or hypotension.

Option B. Sedation and neuromuscular paralysis (e.g., using propofol or benzodiazepines) reduce metabolic demand and prevent agitation, which can increase ICP. Paralysis also reduces the risk of coughing, straining, and increased thoracic pressure, all of which can exacerbate raised ICP.

Key to remember:

Tags:

Topic Name: Cerebrovascular stroke

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 2270

questions.text: A 28-year-old man complaining of 2 day of worsening malaise, weakness, abdominal pain, and discolored dark urine. He was taken Co-trimoxazole for skin infection. His physical examination is notable for mild jaundice, normal vital signs. His complete blood count shows that his hemoglobin has fallen from 13 to 8 g/dL and his bilirubin has gone from normal to 2.5 mg/dL. His urine dipstick is positive for bilirubin. A peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Option D. The peripheral blood smear in shows bite cells, anisocytosis, and spherocytes. The combination of the peripheral smear, jaundice, and hyperbilirubinemia 1 day after receiving sulfamethoxazole makes glucose6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency most likely.

The G6PD gene is X-linked; thus, males have only one G6PDgene (i.e., they are hemizygous for this gene). Therefore, they must be either normal or G6PD deficient.

Hemolytic anemia in patients with G6PD deficiency can develop as a result of fava beans, infections, and drugs.

Common drugs include primaquine, dapsone, sulfamethoxazole, and nitrofurantoin.

Typically, a hemolytic attack starts with malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2-3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine.

There may be hemoglobinemia, hemoglobinuria, high lactate dehydrogenase, and low or absent plasma haptoglobin. G6PD deficiency may be diagnosed by semiquantitative or quantitative red blood cell tests or by DNA testing.

Option A. Iron-deficiency anemia results in microcytic, hypochromic anemia (small, pale red blood cells) on peripheral smear. The patient's acute presentation, jaundice, and peripheral smear findings (bite cells, anisocytosis) are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

Option B. HUS typically causes microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with prominent schistocytes on blood smear, associated with thrombocytopenia and renal failure. This patient's history, smear findings, and drug exposure are more consistent with G6PD deficiency.

Option C. Hereditary spherocytosis causes spherocytes on peripheral smear but is not triggered by sulfa drugs. It is associated with defects in red cell membrane proteins (e.g., spectrin, ankyrin).

Key to remember:

Tags:

Topic Name: G6PD deficiency

Difficulty level: May know

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 784

choices.text: Mediterranean-style diet to reduce calorie intake and improve liver health
Weight loss of 7-10% through sustained lifestyle changes
Regular aerobic or resistance exercise to improve insulin sensitivity
Long-term corticosteroid therapy to reduce liver inflammation

questions.text: All of the following are effective strategies to manage the initial stages of NAFLD depicted in the image EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Image shows: 1 Histopathologic spectrum of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). NAFLD encompasses a dynamic spectrum of liver pathology.

  1. Healthy liver.
  2. Simple steatosis (nonalcoholic fatty liver [NAFL]); arrow shows fatty hepatocyte.
  3. Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH); ballooned hepatocyte (arrow) near central vein with adjacent blue-stained pericellular fibrosis (arrowheads).
  4. Cirrhosis with blue-stained bridging fibrosis surrounding micronodules of liver parenchyma.

Option A. A Mediterranean diet, rich in unsaturated fats and low in processed foods, is recommended to improve liver health and reduce steatosis, even independently of weight loss.

Option B. Sustained weight loss of 5-10% is critical to reversing steatosis and reducing progression to NASH or fibrosis. Greater weight loss improves liver histology.

Option C. Exercise enhances insulin sensitivity, reduces hepatic fat, and complements dietary changes, making it a cornerstone of treatment.

Option D. Corticosteroids are not indicated for NAFLD or NASH and may exacerbate metabolic syndrome, leading to further complications like diabetes or weight gain.(Incorrect)

Key to Remember:

  • NAFLD/NASH treatment prioritizes non-pharmacologic measures such as weight loss and exercise. Corticosteroids are not part of the treatment protocol for NAFLD.

Mnemonic:

  • "F.A.T. = Fix Activity and Tummy":
    • F: Follow a healthy diet (Mediterranean).
    • A: Activity (30 minutes, 5 days/week).
    • T: Target weight loss (7-10%).

Tags:

Topic Name: Liver:NAFLD

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 2620

choices.text: Myxedema coma typically presents with hyperthermia and tachycardia due to increased metabolic demand.
It is a medical emergency associated with severe hypothyroidism, precipitated by stress or infections.
Myxedema coma is primarily caused by adrenal insufficiency and responds immediately to corticosteroid therapy alone.
Serum T3 and T4 levels are elevated, with a concurrent rise in TSH.

questions.text: The clinical image shows a patient with puffiness of the face, coarse features, and nasal broadening. Which of the following statements about myxedema coma is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Option B.

  • Myxedema coma is a life-threatening condition resulting from severe, untreated hypothyroidism.
  • Precipitating factors include infections, surgery, cold exposure, trauma, or sedative use.
  • Clinical features include altered mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypoventilation, and generalized non-pitting edema, as seen in the image (facial puffiness and coarse features).

Option A.

  • Myxedema coma is associated with hypothermia due to decreased metabolic activity.
  • Bradycardia is a hallmark feature due to reduced cardiac output, not tachycardia.

Option C.

  • While adrenal insufficiency may be considered in differential diagnoses, myxedema coma is caused by severe hypothyroidism, and treatment requires thyroid hormone replacement (IV levothyroxine).
  • Corticosteroids are used adjunctively to manage possible adrenal insufficiency, but they are not the primary therapy.

Option D.

  • Myxedema coma is characterized by low free T3 and T4 levels, reflecting hypothyroidism.
  • TSH levels are usually elevated in primary hypothyroidism due to loss of negative feedback.

Key Mnemonic to Remember Myxedema Coma Features:

  • M-Y-X-E-D-E-M-A:
    • M: Mental changes (coma or confusion).
    • Y: Yawning (hypoventilation).
    • X: eXtreme cold (hypothermia).
    • E: Edema (non-pitting, generalized).
    • D: Decreased heart rate (bradycardia).
    • E: Electrolyte imbalance (hyponatremia).
    • M: Myopathy and dry skin.
    • A: Absent reflexes (delayed deep tendon reflexes).

Management of Myxedema Coma:

  1. Immediate IV levothyroxine: Restores thyroid hormone levels.
  2. Hydrocortisone: Administered to manage adrenal insufficiency risk.
  3. Supportive care: Warming blankets, electrolyte correction, and oxygen.
  4. Treat precipitating factors: Infections, sedative withdrawal, etc.

Tags:

Topic Name: Hypothyroidism:Myxedema coma

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 2353

choices.text: Mutation in the PKD1 or PKD2 gene causing defective polycystin proteins
Development of cysts confined exclusively to the kidneys
Onset of renal failure in early childhood
Association with a decreased risk of intracranial aneurysms

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of about the gross specimen shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Photograph showing a kidney from a patient with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. The kidney has been cut open to expose the parenchyma and internal aspects of cysts

Option A.

  • ADPKD is caused by mutations in the PKD1 (85% of cases) or PKD2 (15% of cases) genes, which encode the proteins polycystin-1 and polycystin-2, respectively.
  • These proteins play critical roles in maintaining renal tubular architecture. Their dysfunction leads to abnormal cyst development, as shown in the image.

Option B.

  • ADPKD is a systemic disorder, and cysts can also form in the liver, pancreas, seminal vesicles, and rarely in the arachnoid membranes.
  • Extrarenal manifestations like hepatic cysts and mitral valve prolapse are common.

Option C.

  • ADPKD typically manifests in adulthood, with renal failure usually occurring after the age of 40-50 years.
  • In contrast, autosomal recessive PKD (ARPKD) presents in infancy or early childhood with severe renal and hepatic dysfunction.

Option D.

  • ADPKD is associated with an increased risk of intracranial aneurysms (especially in the Circle of Willis), which can cause life-threatening subarachnoid hemorrhages.
  • Screening is recommended in patients with a family history of aneurysms or in high-risk occupations.

Mnemonic to Remember ADPKD Features:

  • CYST:
    • C: Cysts in kidney and liver.
    • Y: Years (adult-onset).
    • S: Increased risk of Stroke (aneurysms).
    • T: Two genes: PKD1 and PKD2.

Key features to remember:

Tags:

Topic Name: Kidney disease:sADPKD

Difficulty level: Good to know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, Principles of Internal medicine, Page number 2353
